Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Identified that the durations of cases can be calculated using timestamps from Submit Claim to Close Claim.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Realized that cases 2003 and 2005 have significantly longer durations compared to the other cases.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Noted that high-complexity cases tend to involve multiple requests for additional documents, leading to extended durations.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Observed that cases 2003 and 2005 have 3 and 4 Request Additional Documents events respectively, whereas other cases have none or only one.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Concluded that multiple requests for additional documents in high-complexity cases are a key factor in longer processing times.

Name: Abductive Reasoning - IND
Text: Speculated that Regions A and B might have bottlenecks or higher complexity workloads, contributing to delays.

Name: Inductive Reasoning - IND
Text: Noted that Region B in particular has medium and low complexity cases that finish quickly, but high-complexity cases still take longer, suggesting complexity is the dominant factor.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Concluded that resource capacity constraints might contribute to inefficiencies but are secondary to the number of requests in high-complexity cases.

Name: Hypothesis Generation - PE
Text: Formulated the hypothesis that automating document validation and approvals could directly reduce delays caused by iterative requests.

Name: Validation - PE
Text: Evaluated the durations of the other cases to confirm that only high-complexity cases with multiple requests exhibit significantly longer durations.
